Comment: There is already a falling sand puzzle but this one is different enough and much easier. I especially liked the chess opening test cases :-)

Comment: I liked it.  Nice intro to the hourglass puzzle.
The Statement doesn't explain or hint at what the number after the letter means, and it's not obvious. You have to jump down to the Input to understand that.

I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I think the problem could be simplified in a few ways, like using the same movement rules for all grains (instead of making a distinction between lowercase and uppercase letters) and explaining the "overflow" condition earlier with clearer examples. These changes would make the problem easier to understand and less confusing, especially for developers encountering it for the first time.

Did you get the idea for this challenge from Advent of Code?
https://adventofcode.com/2022/day/14

The problem was enjoyable, but I found it a bit complex. I had fun solving it, though it took me more time than expected to fully understand what was required. The main challenge for me was understanding the problem description. When I tried to apply my algorithms, I realized that I had built them on incorrect assumptions, which happened because I was struggling to grasp the details of the problem.

I think the problem could be simplified in a few ways, like using the same movement rules for all grains (instead of making a distinction between lowercase and uppercase letters) and explaining the "overflow" condition earlier with clearer examples. These changes would make the problem easier to understand and less confusing, especially for developers encountering it for the first time.

Goal
* Please add a full-stop after "A-Z".

* Please fix the typo: bellow => below.

* It is not clear when a grain will move right or left. Suggest to add a rule to clarify that, e.g.

   â€¢ If there is not an empty space directly below it, but there is space lower down towards a specific horizontal direction (left or right, see the next two rules), then it will move horizontally in that direction before falling down again.

* Please add "and then" before "towards" (twice).

* The last rule does not seem to comply with the law of physics (the sand should fall outside the box instead of not falling). Suggest to delete it, and then add a new paragraph to explain "overflow".

Input
* Please change "[[n]] following lines:" to "<<Next [[n]] lines>>:".

* Please change "it's" to "its".

* Please add the following after "[[p]]":
above the box, separated by a space. [[p]] = 0 if it is above the left edge of the box, and [[p]] = [[w]] - 1 if it is above the right edge of the box.

Output
* Please change "[[h]] lines:" to "<<[[h]] lines:>>".

* Please mention that any unoccupied space of the box should be filled with the space character, which should not be removed in the output.

* Please format "OVERFLOW" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

Constraints
* Please format the last "w" as a [[variable]].

Cases
* Suggest to amend [[w]], [[h]] and [[p]] slightly in all the validators so that there are some more variations.

Thanks.
Done, thanks for your time!

Great feedback, thank you very much!

I already felt the rules where a tad hard to grasp (if not poorly explained) when discussing with @5DN1L, I might just get rid of the "overflow" condition and state in the constraints that the grains always fit inside the box.

The uppercase/lowercase rule is there to implement some sort of randomness, I will try to keep it for now and add more test cases with only a few grains to help better understand the physics.

No, I got it from The coding train, coding challenge 180.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L4u7Zy_b868
I take this as you agreeing with what @walhamad said 3 days ago.

Hi and thanks @Jp82 for taking the time to comment.
Glad you liked it, cheers!
Correct, thank you!

Thank you for following up!

Goal
* I think this part can be removed without affecting the explanation: (y < 0 if you consider y = 0 as top of the box or y >= h if you consider y = 0 as bottom of the box).

Cases
* Example Validator: Can you explain why the letter "A" does not fall further down towards the right?

Thanks again.

V Removed :)

The letter 'A' is falling on top of 'N' in "ONE", it first checks 'N' (can't go there), then checks 'O'[=left] because 'A' is uppercase (can't go on 'O' either), then checks 'E'[=right] (can't go on 'E' either). As it can't go down, to the left, nor to the right, it has reached its final position, it doesn't matter that there is space to the right or to the left of "ONE".

I guess I should make a step by step example to make sure solvers don't try to go right or left indefinitely? I only meant for grains to check the 3 cells below them.

Oh. I think you do have to emphasise the "3-cell" rule, which is currently not clear from the statement. Please also emphasise that the 3-cell rule will apply as long as a grain is located where one of the 3 cells down below is still empty.
I tried to make a step by step example covering the 3-cell rule, as I feel there are already a lot of rules and I don't like puzzles with a wall of rules. Let me know if this works out for you.
Please change "lower down towards a specific horizontal direction" to "at either <<diagonally adjacent>> position below". Hopefully this will be clear enough to imply the 3-cell rule. Thanks.

4 1
4
D 0
o 0
n 2
e 2

Thanks again for your time.
ty

Goal
* For the step-by-step explanation of the example, it's better to move your explanation for each state below that state, because some of the words on the longer lines cannot be shown on a narrow screen.

Thanks.

Very pertinent, I overlooked it.

Thanks.

"[[p]] = 0 if it is above the left edge of the box, and [[p]] = [[w]] - 1 if it is above the right edge of the box."

It now looks a bit confusing to me although I proposed that wording myself ðŸ¤”. Should we revise it to "[[p]] = 0 if it is above the first {{-}}, and [[p]] = [[w]] -1 if it is above the last {{-}}"?

To be fair, the box wasnÂ´t outlined in the output when you proposed "edges" of the box.

I changed it for now to "[[p]] = 0 if it is above the left-most column, and [[p]] = [[w]] -1 if it is above the right-most column" as the underlying "+----+" line of the box is only introduced in the output section down below.

Ah, I see!
Your wording should work too, thanks!
